<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pre-history_of_the_Castle_Rock">Pre-history of the Castle Rock</span></h3>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Geology">Geology</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Crag_and_tail.png" title="File:Crag and tail.png">File:Crag and tail.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Diagram of a crag and tail feature, such as the Castle Rock: <b>A</b> is the crag formed from the volcanic plug, <b>B</b> is the tail of softer rock, and <b>C</b> shows the direction of ice movement. In the case of Edinburgh, the castle stands on the crag (<b>A</b>) with the Royal Mile extending along the tail (<b>B</b>)</div></div></div>
<p>The castle stands upon the <a href="/wiki/Volcanic_plug" title="Volcanic plug">plug</a> of an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Extinct_volcano&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Extinct volcano (page does not exist)">extinct volcano</a>, which is estimated to have risen some 350 million years ago during the lower <a href="/wiki/Carboniferous" title="Carboniferous">Carboniferous</a> period. The Castle Rock is the remains of a <a href="/wiki/Volcanic_pipe" title="Volcanic pipe">volcanic pipe</a>, which cut through the surrounding sedimentary rock before cooling to form very hard <a href="/wiki/Dolerite" title="Dolerite" class="mw-redirect">dolerite</a>, a type of basalt. Subsequent <a href="/wiki/Glaciology" title="Glaciology">glacial erosion</a> was resisted by the dolerite, which protected the softer rock to the east, leaving a <a href="/wiki/Crag_and_tail" title="Crag and tail">crag and tail</a> formation.<sup id="cite_ref-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-3">[3]</a></sup>
</p><p>The summit of the Castle Rock is <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> above sea level, with rocky cliffs to the south, west and north, rising to a height of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> above the surrounding landscape.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> This means that the only readily accessible route to the castle lies to the east, where the ridge slopes more gently. The defensive advantage of such a site is self-evident, but the geology of the rock also presents difficulties, since basalt is extremely impermeable. Providing water to the Upper Ward of the castle was problematic, and despite the sinking of a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> deep well, the water supply often ran out during drought or siege,<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> for example during the Lang Siege in 1573.<sup id="cite_ref-Potter137_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Potter137-6">[6]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Earliest_habitation">Earliest habitation</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh_Castle_from_Portsburgh.jpg" title="File:Edinburgh Castle from Portsburgh.jpg">File:Edinburgh Castle from Portsburgh.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The castle is built on a volcanic rock, as seen here from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=West_Port,_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="West Port, Edinburgh (page does not exist)">West Port</a> area</div></div></div>
<p>Archaeological investigation has yet to establish when the Castle Rock was first used as a place of human habitation. There is no record of any Roman interest in the location during <a href="/wiki/Gnaeus_Julius_Agricola" title="Gnaeus Julius Agricola">General Agricola</a>'s invasion of northern Britain near the end of the 1st century AD. <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>'s map of the 2nd century AD <sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup> shows a settlement in the territory of the <a href="/wiki/Votadini" title="Votadini">Votadini</a> named "Alauna", meaning "rock place", making this possibly the earliest known name for the Castle Rock.<sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup> This could, however, refer to another of the tribe's hill forts in the area. The <i>Orygynale Cronykil</i> of <a href="/wiki/Andrew_of_Wyntoun" title="Andrew of Wyntoun">Andrew of Wyntoun</a> (c. 1350 – c. 1423), an early source for <a href="/wiki/Scottish_history" title="Scottish history" class="mw-redirect">Scottish history</a>, names "Ebrawce" (<a href="/wiki/Ebraucus" title="Ebraucus">Ebraucus</a>), a <a href="/wiki/List_of_legendary_kings_of_Britain" title="List of legendary kings of Britain">legendary King of the Britons</a>, as having "byggyd [built] Edynburgh".<sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup> According to the earlier chronicler, <a href="/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth" title="Geoffrey of Monmouth">Geoffrey of Monmouth</a> (c. 1100 – c. 1155), Ebraucus had fifty children by his twenty wives, and was the founder of "Kaerebrauc" (<a href="/wiki/York" title="York">York</a>), "Alclud" (<a href="/wiki/Dumbarton" title="Dumbarton">Dumbarton</a>) and the "Maidens' Castle".<sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> The 16th-century English writer <a href="/wiki/John_Stow" title="John Stow">John Stow</a> (c. 1525 – 1605), credited Ebraucus with building "the Castell of Maidens called Edenbrough" in 989 BC.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup>
The name "Maiden Castle" (Latin <i>Castellum Puellarum</i>) occurs frequently up until the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup>  It appears in charters of <a href="/wiki/David_I_of_Scotland" title="David I of Scotland">David I</a> (r.1124–1153) and his successors,<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> although the reason for it is not known.  <a href="/wiki/William_Camden" title="William Camden">William Camden</a>'s survey of Britain, <i>Britannia</i> (1607), records that "the Britans called [it] Castle Myned Agned [winged rock], the Scots, the Maidens Castle and the Virgins Castle, of certaine young maidens of the Picts roiall bloud who were kept there in old time".<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup>  According to the 17th-century antiquarian Father Richard Hay, the "maidens" were a group of nuns, who were ejected from the castle and replaced by <a href="/wiki/Canon_(priest)" title="Canon (priest)">canons</a>, considered "fitter to live among soldiers".<sup id="cite_ref-15" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-15">[15]</a></sup>  However, this story was considered "apocryphal" by the 19th-century antiquarian <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Wilson_(academic)" title="Daniel Wilson (academic)">Daniel Wilson</a> and has been ignored by historians since.<sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup>  The name may have been derived from a "Cult of the Nine Maidens" type of legend. <a href="/wiki/Arthurian_legend" title="Arthurian legend" class="mw-redirect">Arthurian legends</a> suggest that the site once held a shrine to <a href="/wiki/Morgan_le_Fay" title="Morgan le Fay">Morgain la Fee</a>, one of nine sisters.<sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-17">[17]</a></sup>  Later, St Monenna, said to be one of nine companions, reputedly invested a church at Edinburgh, as well as at Dumbarton and other places.<sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-18">[18]</a></sup> More simply, the term "Maiden Castle" may have implied a castle that had never been taken by force.<sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-19">[19]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh_Castle_from_the_North.JPG" title="File:Edinburgh Castle from the North.JPG">File:Edinburgh Castle from the North.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Castle seen from the North</div></div></div>
<p>An archaeological excavation in the early 1990s uncovered evidence of the site having been settled during the late <a href="/wiki/Bronze_Age" title="Bronze Age">Bronze Age</a> or early <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age" title="Iron Age">Iron Age</a>, potentially making the Castle Rock the longest continually occupied site in Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> However, the extent of the finds was not particularly significant and was insufficient to draw any certain conclusions about the precise nature or scale of this earliest known phase of occupation.<sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-21">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>The archaeological evidence is more reliable in respect of the Iron Age. Traditionally, it had been supposed that the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_people&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish people (page does not exist)">tribes</a> of central Scotland had made little or no use of the Castle Rock. Excavations at nearby <a href="/wiki/Arthur%27s_Seat" title="Arthur's Seat">Dunsapie Hill</a>, <a href="/wiki/Duddingston" title="Duddingston">Duddingston</a>, <a href="/wiki/Inveresk" title="Inveresk">Inveresk</a> and <a href="/wiki/Traprain_Law" title="Traprain Law">Traprain Law</a> had revealed relatively large settlements and it was supposed that these sites had been chosen in preference to the Castle Rock. However, the excavation in the 1990s pointed to the probable existence of an enclosed <a href="/wiki/Hill_fort" title="Hill fort">hill fort</a> on the rock, although only the fringes of the site were excavated. House fragments revealed were similar to Iron Age dwellings previously found in Northumbria.<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>The 1990s dig revealed clear signs of habitation from the 1st and 2nd centuries AD, consistent with <a href="/wiki/Ptolemy" title="Ptolemy">Ptolemy</a>'s reference to "Alauna". Signs of occupation included some <a href="/wiki/Roman_Britain" title="Roman Britain">Roman</a> material, including pottery, bronzes and brooches, implying a possible trading relationship between the Votadini and the Romans beginning with <a href="/wiki/Gnaeus_Julius_Agricola" title="Gnaeus Julius Agricola">Agricola's</a> northern campaign in AD 82, and continuing through to the establishment of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antonine_Wall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antonine Wall (page does not exist)">Antonine Wall</a> around AD 140. The nature of the settlement in this period is inconclusive, but Driscoll and Yeoman suggest it may have been a <a href="/wiki/Broch" title="Broch">broch</a>, similar to the one at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edin%27s_Hall_Broch&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edin's Hall Broch (page does not exist)">Edin's Hall</a> near <a href="/wiki/Duns" title="Duns">Duns</a> in the <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Borders" title="Scottish Borders">Scottish Borders</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-23" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-23">[23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_Middle_Ages">Early Middle Ages</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Yr.Hen.Ogledd.550.650.Koch.jpg" title="File:Yr.Hen.Ogledd.550.650.Koch.jpg">File:Yr.Hen.Ogledd.550.650.Koch.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Map of northern Britain showing the Gododdin and other tribes c.600 AD</div></div></div>
<p>The castle does not re-appear in contemporary historical records from the time of Ptolemy until around AD 600. Then, in the epic <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Welsh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Welsh (page does not exist)">Welsh</a> poem <i><a href="/wiki/Y_Gododdin" title="Y Gododdin">Y Gododdin</a></i> there is a reference to <i>Din Eidyn</i>, "the stronghold of Eidyn". This has been generally assumed to refer to the Castle Rock.<sup id="cite_ref-24" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-24">[24]</a></sup> The poem tells of the <a href="/wiki/Gododdin" title="Gododdin">Gododdin</a> King <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mynyddog_Mwynfawr&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mynyddog Mwynfawr (page does not exist)">Mynyddog Mwynfawr</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> and his band of warriors, who, after a year of feasting in their fortress, set out to do battle with the <a href="/wiki/Angles" title="Angles">Angles</a> at "Catreath" (possibly <a href="/w/index.php?title=Catterick,_North_Yorkshire&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Catterick, North Yorkshire (page does not exist)">Catterick</a>) in Yorkshire. Despite performing glorious deeds of valour and bravery, the poem relates that the Gododdin were massacred.<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Irish_annals&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Irish annals (page does not exist)">Irish annals</a> record that in 638, after the events related in <i>Y Gododdin</i>, "Etin" was besieged by the Angles under <a href="/wiki/Oswald_of_Northumbria" title="Oswald of Northumbria">Oswald of Northumbria</a>, and the Gododdin were defeated.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup> The territory around Edinburgh then became part of the <a href="/wiki/Northumbria" title="Northumbria">Kingdom of Northumbria</a>, which was itself absorbed by <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">England</a> in the 10th century, when <a href="/w/index.php?title=Athelstan_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Athelstan of England (page does not exist)">Athelstan of England</a>, according to the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Annals_of_Clonmacnoise&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Annals of Clonmacnoise (page does not exist)">Annals of Clonmacnoise</a>, "spoiled the Kingdom to Edinburgh".<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup> The English withdrew, and Lothian became part of Scotland, during the reign of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Indulf_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Indulf of Scotland (page does not exist)">Indulf</a> (r.954–962).<sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>The archaeological evidence for the period in question is based entirely on the analysis of <a href="/wiki/Midden" title="Midden">middens</a> (domestic refuse heaps), with no evidence of structures. Few conclusions can therefore be derived about the status of the settlement during this period, although the midden deposits show no clear break since Roman times.<sup id="cite_ref-DY227_30-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-DY227-30">[30]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:StMargareth_edinburgh_castle.jpg" title="File:StMargareth edinburgh castle.jpg">File:StMargareth edinburgh castle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">St Margaret, depicted in a stained glass window in the chapel of Edinburgh Castle</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="High_Middle_Ages">High Middle Ages</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Further2&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Further2 (page does not exist)">Template:Further2</a>
</p><p>The first documentary reference to a <a href="/wiki/Castle" title="Castle">castle</a> at Edinburgh is <a href="/wiki/John_of_Fordun" title="John of Fordun">John of Fordun's</a> account of the death of <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_III_of_Scotland" title="Malcolm III of Scotland">King Malcolm III</a>. Fordun describes his widow, the future <a href="/wiki/Saint_Margaret_of_Scotland" title="Saint Margaret of Scotland">Saint Margaret</a>, as residing at the "Castle of Maidens" when she is brought news of his death in November 1093. Fordun's account goes on to relate how Margaret died of grief within days, and how Malcolm's brother <a href="/wiki/Donald_III_of_Scotland" title="Donald III of Scotland">Donald Bane</a> laid siege to the castle. However, Fordun's chronicle was not written until the later 14th century, and the near-contemporary account of the life of St Margaret by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thurgot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thurgot (page does not exist)">Bishop Turgot</a> makes no mention of a castle.<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> During the reigns of Malcolm III and his sons, Edinburgh Castle became one of the most significant royal centres in Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-MI28_32-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI28-32">[32]</a></sup> Malcolm's son <a href="/wiki/Edgar_I_of_Scotland" title="Edgar I of Scotland" class="mw-redirect">King Edgar</a> died here in 1107.<sup id="cite_ref-MI30_33-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI30-33">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>Malcolm's youngest son, <a href="/wiki/David_I_of_Scotland" title="David I of Scotland">King David I</a> (r.1124–1153), developed Edinburgh as a seat of royal power principally through his administrative reforms (termed by some modern scholars the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Davidian_Revolution&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Davidian Revolution (page does not exist)">Davidian Revolution</a>).<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup> Between 1139 and 1150, David held an assembly of nobles and churchmen, a precursor to the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland" title="Parliament of Scotland">parliament of Scotland</a>, at the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-MI28_32-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI28-32">[32]</a></sup> Any buildings or defences would probably have been of timber,<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham2008-49_35-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham2008-49-35">[35]</a></sup> although two stone buildings are documented as having existed in the 12th century. Of these, <a href="/w/index.php?title=St._Margaret%27s_Chapel&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="St. Margaret's Chapel (page does not exist)">St. Margaret's Chapel</a> remains at the summit of the rock. The second was a church, dedicated to <a href="/wiki/St._Mary" title="St. Mary" class="mw-redirect">St. Mary</a>, which stood on the site of the Scottish National War Memorial.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham2008-49_35-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham2008-49-35">[35]</a></sup> Given that the southern part of the Upper Ward (where Crown Square is now sited) was not suited to being built upon until the construction of the vaults in the 15th century, it seems probable that any earlier buildings would have been located towards the northern part of the rock; that is around the area where St. Margaret's Chapel stands. This has led to a suggestion that the chapel is the last remnant of a square, stone keep, which would have formed the bulk of the 12th-century fortification.<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> The structure may have been similar to the keep of <a href="/wiki/Carlisle_Castle" title="Carlisle Castle">Carlisle Castle</a>, which David I began after 1135.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.23_37-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.23-37">[37]</a></sup>
</p><p>David's successor <a href="/wiki/Malcolm_IV_of_Scotland" title="Malcolm IV of Scotland">King Malcolm IV</a> (r.1153–1165) reportedly stayed at Edinburgh more than at any other location.<sup id="cite_ref-MI30_33-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI30-33">[33]</a></sup> But in 1174, <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_I_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William I of Scotland (page does not exist)">King William "the Lion"</a> (r.1165–1214) was captured by the English at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Alnwick_(1174)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of Alnwick (1174) (page does not exist)">Battle of Alnwick</a>. He was forced to sign the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Falaise&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Falaise (page does not exist)">Treaty of Falaise</a> to secure his release, in return for surrendering Edinburgh Castle, along with the castles of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Berwick_Castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Berwick Castle (page does not exist)">Berwick</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roxburgh_Castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roxburgh Castle (page does not exist)">Roxburgh</a> and <a href="/wiki/Stirling_Castle" title="Stirling Castle">Stirling</a>, to the English King, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Henry_II_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Henry II of England (page does not exist)">Henry II</a>. The castle was occupied by the English for twelve years, until 1186, when it was returned to William as the <a href="/wiki/Dowry" title="Dowry">dowry</a> of his English bride, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ermengarde_de_Beaumont&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ermengarde de Beaumont (page does not exist)">Ermengarde de Beaumont</a>, who had been chosen for him by King Henry.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter46_38-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter46-38">[38]</a></sup> By the end of the 12th century, Edinburgh Castle was established as the main repository of Scotland's official state papers.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Wars_of_Scottish_Independence">Wars of Scottish Independence</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:RobertBruceAndWilliamWallace.jpg" title="File:RobertBruceAndWilliamWallace.jpg">File:RobertBruceAndWilliamWallace.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Statues of Robert the Bruce by Thomas Clapperton and William Wallace by Alexander Carrick were added to the Gatehouse entrance in 1929</div></div></div>
<p>A century later, in 1286, on the death of <a href="/wiki/Alexander_III_of_Scotland" title="Alexander III of Scotland">King Alexander III</a>, the throne of Scotland became vacant. <a href="/wiki/Edward_I_of_England" title="Edward I of England">Edward I of England</a> was appointed to adjudicate the <a href="/wiki/Competitors_for_the_Crown_of_Scotland" title="Competitors for the Crown of Scotland">competing claims</a> for the Scottish crown, but used the opportunity to attempt to establish himself as the feudal overlord of Scotland. During the negotiations, Edward stayed briefly at Edinburgh Castle and may have received homage there from the Scottish nobles.<sup id="cite_ref-MacIvor33_40-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacIvor33-40">[40]</a></sup>
</p><p>In March 1296, Edward I launched an invasion of Scotland, unleashing the <a href="/wiki/First_War_of_Scottish_Independence" title="First War of Scottish Independence">First War of Scottish Independence</a>. Edinburgh Castle soon came under English control, surrendering after a three days long bombardment.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Following the siege, Edward had many of the Scottish legal records and royal treasures moved from the castle to England.<sup id="cite_ref-MacIvor33_40-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacIvor33-40">[40]</a></sup> A large garrison numbering 325 men was installed in 1300.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> Edward also brought to Scotland his master builders of the Welsh castles, including Thomas de Houghton and Master Walter of Hereford, both of whom travelled from Wales to Edinburgh.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> After the death of Edward I in 1307, however, England's control over Scotland weakened. On 14 March 1314, a surprise night attack by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Randolph,_1st_Earl_of_Moray" title="Thomas Randolph, 1st Earl of Moray">Thomas Randolph, 1st Earl of Moray</a> recaptured the castle. <a href="/wiki/John_Barbour_(poet)" title="John Barbour (poet)">John Barbour</a>'s narrative poem <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=The_Brus&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="The Brus (page does not exist)">The Brus</a></i> relates how a party of thirty hand-picked men were guided by one William Francis, a member of the garrison who knew of a route along the north face of the Castle Rock and a place where the wall might be scaled. Making the difficult ascent, Randolph's men scaled the wall, surprised the garrison and took control.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Robert_the_Bruce" title="Robert the Bruce">Robert the Bruce</a> immediately ordered the destruction of the castle's defences to prevent its re-occupation by the English.<sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> Four months later, his army secured victory at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bannockburn" title="Battle of Bannockburn">Battle of Bannockburn</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-46">[46]</a></sup>
</p><p>After Bruce's death in 1329, <a href="/wiki/Edward_III_of_England" title="Edward III of England">Edward III of England</a> determined to renew the attempted subjugation of Scotland and supported the claim of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edward_Balliol&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edward Balliol (page does not exist)">Edward Balliol</a>, son of the former King <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John of Scotland (page does not exist)">John Balliol</a>, over that of Bruce's young son <a href="/wiki/David_II_of_Scotland" title="David II of Scotland">David II</a>. Edward invaded in 1333, marking the start of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_War_of_Scottish_Independence&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second War of Scottish Independence (page does not exist)">Second War of Scottish Independence</a>, and the English forces reoccupied and refortified Edinburgh Castle in 1335,<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham2008-51_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham2008-51-47">[47]</a></sup> holding it until 1341. This time, the Scottish assault was led by <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Douglas,_Lord_of_Liddesdale&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Douglas, Lord of Liddesdale (page does not exist)">William Douglas, Lord of Liddesdale</a>. Douglas's party disguised themselves as merchants from <a href="/wiki/Leith" title="Leith">Leith</a> bringing supplies to the garrison. Driving a cart into the entrance, they halted it there to prevent the gates closing. A larger force hidden nearby rushed to join them and the castle was retaken.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter46_38-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter46-38">[38]</a></sup> The English garrison, numbering 100, were all killed.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham2008-51_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham2008-51-47">[47]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="David.27s_Tower_and_the_15th_century">David's Tower and the 15th century</span></h3>
<p>The 1357 <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Berwick_(1357)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Berwick (1357) (page does not exist)">Treaty of Berwick</a> brought the Wars of Independence to a close. David II resumed his rule and set about rebuilding Edinburgh Castle which became his principal seat of government.<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> David's Tower was begun around 1367, and was incomplete when David died at the castle in 1371. It was completed by his successor, <a href="/wiki/Robert_II_of_Scotland" title="Robert II of Scotland">Robert II</a>, in the 1370s. The tower stood on the site of the present Half Moon Battery and was connected by a section of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Curtain_wall_(fortification)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Curtain wall (fortification) (page does not exist)">curtain wall</a> to the smaller Constable's Tower, a round tower built between 1375 and 1379 where the Portcullis Gate now stands.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter46_38-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter46-38">[38]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Braun_%26_Hogenberg_%27Castrum_Puellarum%27_(Edinburgh_Castle)_c.1581.jpg" title="File:Braun &amp; Hogenberg 'Castrum Puellarum' (Edinburgh Castle) c.1581.jpg">File:Braun &amp; Hogenberg 'Castrum Puellarum' (Edinburgh Castle) c.1581.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A late-16th-century depiction of the castle, from Braun &amp; Hogenberg's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Georg_Braun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Georg Braun (page does not exist)"><i>Civitates orbis terrarum</i></a>, showing David's Tower at the centre</div></div></div>
<p>In the early 15th century, another English invasion, this time under <a href="/wiki/Henry_IV_of_England" title="Henry IV of England">Henry IV</a>, reached Edinburgh Castle and began a siege, but eventually withdrew due to lack of supplies.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter46_38-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter46-38">[38]</a></sup> From 1437, Sir <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Crichton,_1st_Lord_Crichton&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Crichton, 1st Lord Crichton (page does not exist)">William Crichton</a> was Keeper of Edinburgh Castle,<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-50">[50]</a></sup> and soon after became <a href="/w/index.php?title=Chancellor_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Chancellor of Scotland (page does not exist)">Chancellor of Scotland</a>. In an attempt to gain the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regent (page does not exist)">regency</a> of Scotland, Crichton sought to break the power of the <a href="/wiki/Earl_of_Douglas" title="Earl of Douglas">Douglases</a>, the principal noble family in the kingdom. The sixteen-year-old <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Douglas,_6th_Earl_of_Douglas&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Douglas, 6th Earl of Douglas (page does not exist)">William Douglas, 6th Earl of Douglas</a> and his younger brother David were summoned to Edinburgh Castle in November 1440. After the so-called "Black Dinner" had taken place in David's Tower, both boys were summarily executed on trumped-up charges in the presence of the ten-year-old <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_Scotland" title="James II of Scotland">King James II</a> (r.1437–1460). Douglas' supporters subsequently besieged the castle, inflicting damage.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup> Construction continued throughout this period, with the area now known as Crown Square being laid out over <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vault_(architecture)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vault (architecture) (page does not exist)">vaults</a> in the 1430s. Royal apartments were built, forming the nucleus of the later palace block, and a Great Hall was in existence by 1458. In 1464, access to the castle was improved when the current approach road up the north-east side of the rock was created to allow easier movement of the royal artillery train in and out of the area now known as the Upper Ward.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1479, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Stewart,_Duke_of_Albany" title="Alexander Stewart, Duke of Albany">Alexander Stewart, Duke of Albany</a>, was imprisoned in David's Tower for plotting against his brother, <a href="/wiki/James_III_of_Scotland" title="James III of Scotland">King James III</a> (r.1460–1488). He escaped by getting his guards drunk, then lowering himself from a window on a rope.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup> Albany fled to France, then England, where he allied himself with <a href="/wiki/Edward_IV_of_England" title="Edward IV of England">King Edward IV</a>. In 1482, Albany <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capture_of_Berwick_(1482)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Capture of Berwick (1482) (page does not exist)">marched into Scotland</a> with <a href="/wiki/Richard_III_of_England" title="Richard III of England">Richard, Duke of Gloucester</a> (later King Richard III) and an English army. James III was trapped in the castle from 22 July to 29 September 1482 until he successfully negotiated a settlement.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Impression_of_Edinburgh_Castle_before_the_%27Lang_Siege%27_of_1573.jpg" title="File:Impression of Edinburgh Castle before the 'Lang Siege' of 1573.jpg">File:Impression of Edinburgh Castle before the 'Lang Siege' of 1573.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Edinburgh Castle as it may have looked before the Lang Siege of 1571-73, with David's Tower and the Palace block, centre and left</div></div></div>
<p>During the 15th century the castle was increasingly used as an <a href="/wiki/Arsenal" title="Arsenal">arsenal</a> and armaments factory. The first known purchase of a gun was in 1384, and the "great <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bombard_(weapon)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bombard (weapon) (page does not exist)">bombard</a>" <a href="/wiki/Mons_Meg" title="Mons Meg">Mons Meg</a> was delivered to Edinburgh in 1457.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.76_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.76-52">[52]</a></sup> The first recorded mention of an <a href="/wiki/Armory_(military)" title="Armory (military)">armoury</a> for the manufacture of guns occurs in 1474, and by 1498 the master gunner Robert Borthwick was casting bronze guns at Edinburgh.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> By 1511 Edinburgh was the principal foundry in Scotland, supplanting Stirling Castle, with Scottish and European smiths working under Borthwick, who by 1512 was appointed "master melter of the king's guns".<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> Their output included guns for the Scottish flagship, the "<i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Great_Michael&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Great Michael (page does not exist)">Great Michael</a></i>", and the "Seven Sisters", a set of cannon captured by the English at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Flodden" title="Battle of Flodden">Flodden</a> in 1513.<sup id="cite_ref-55" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-55">[55]</a></sup> Sir Thomas Howard, England's Lord Admiral, admired their graceful shape and brilliant finish, declaring them the most beautiful [cannon] for their size and length that he had ever seen.<sup id="cite_ref-56" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-56">[56]</a></sup> From 1510 Dutch craftsmen were also producing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hand_culverin&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hand culverin (page does not exist)">hand culverins</a>, an early <a href="/wiki/Firearm" title="Firearm">firearm</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> After Flodden, Borthwick continued his work, producing an unknown number of guns, of which none survive. He was succeeded by French smiths, who began manufacturing <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hagbut&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hagbut (page does not exist)">hagbuts</a> (another type of firearm) in the 1550s,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> and by 1541 the castle had a stock of 413.<sup id="cite_ref-59" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-59">[59]</a></sup>
</p><p>Meanwhile, the royal family began to stay more frequently at the <a href="/wiki/Holyrood_Abbey" title="Holyrood Abbey">Abbey of Holyrood</a>, about a mile from the castle. Around the end of the fifteenth century, <a href="/wiki/James_IV_of_Scotland" title="James IV of Scotland">King James IV</a> (r.1488–1513) built <a href="/w/index.php?title=Holyrood_Palace&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Holyrood Palace (page does not exist)">Holyroodhouse</a>, by the abbey, as his principal Edinburgh residence, and the castle's role as a royal home subsequently declined.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup> James IV did, however, construct the Great Hall, which was completed in the early 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="16th_century_and_the_Lang_Siege">16th century and the Lang Siege</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Jean_Clouet_004.jpg" title="File:Jean Clouet 004.jpg">File:Jean Clouet 004.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sir William Kirkcaldy of Grange, who held the castle on behalf of Queen Mary during the Lang Siege of 1571-73. Painting by <a href="/wiki/Jean_Clouet" title="Jean Clouet">Jean Clouet</a></div></div></div>
<p>James IV was killed in battle at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Battle_of_Flodden_Field&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Battle of Flodden Field (page does not exist)">Flodden Field</a>, on 9 September 1513. Expecting the English to press their advantage, the Scots hastily constructed a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edinburgh_town_walls&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edinburgh town walls (page does not exist)">town wall</a> around Edinburgh and augmented the castle's defences. Robert Borthwick and a Frenchman, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Antoine_d%27Arces&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Antoine d'Arces (page does not exist)">Antoine d'Arces</a>, were involved in designing new artillery defences and fortifications in 1514, though it appears from lack of evidence that little of the planned work was carried out.<sup id="cite_ref-60" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-60">[60]</a></sup> Three years later, <a href="/wiki/James_V_of_Scotland" title="James V of Scotland">King James V</a> (r.1513–1542), still only five years old, was brought to the castle for safety.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup> Upon his death 25 years later, the crown passed to his week-old daughter, <a href="/wiki/Mary,_Queen_of_Scots" title="Mary, Queen of Scots">Mary, Queen of Scots</a>. English invasions followed, as <a href="/wiki/Henry_VIII_of_England" title="Henry VIII of England">King Henry VIII</a> attempted to force a dynastic marriage on Scotland, although Edinburgh Castle remained largely unaffected.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup> Following these campaigns, refortifications included an earthen angle-bastion, known as the Spur, of the type known as <i><a href="/wiki/Trace_italienne" title="Trace italienne" class="mw-redirect">trace italienne</a></i>, one of the earliest examples in Britain.<sup id="cite_ref-tab104_61-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tab104-61">[61]</a></sup> It may have been designed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Migiliorino_Ubaldini&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Migiliorino Ubaldini (page does not exist)">Migiliorino Ubaldini</a>, an Italian engineer from the court of <a href="/wiki/Henry_II_of_France" title="Henry II of France">Henry II of France</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-tab104_61-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tab104-61">[61]</a></sup> and was said to have the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coat_of_Arms_of_France&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coat of Arms of France (page does not exist)">arms of France</a> carved on it.<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> James V's widow, <a href="/wiki/Mary_of_Guise" title="Mary of Guise">Mary of Guise</a>, acted as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regent&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regent (page does not exist)">regent</a> from 1554 until her death at the castle in 1560.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>The following year, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Roman_Catholicism_in_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Roman Catholicism in Scotland (page does not exist)">Catholic</a> Mary, Queen of Scots, returned from France to begin her reign, which was marred by crises and quarrels amongst the powerful <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_Reformation&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish Reformation (page does not exist)">Protestant</a> Scottish nobility. In 1565, the Queen made an unpopular marriage with <a href="/wiki/Henry_Stuart,_Lord_Darnley" title="Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley">Henry Stuart, Lord Darnley</a>, and the following year, in a small room of the Palace at Edinburgh Castle, she gave birth to their son <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_I_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James I of England (page does not exist)">James</a>, who would later be King of both Scotland and England. Mary's reign was, however, brought to an abrupt end. Three months after the  murder of Darnley at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Kirk_o%27_Field&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Kirk o' Field (page does not exist)">Kirk o' Field</a> in 1567, she married <a href="/wiki/James_Hepburn,_4th_Earl_of_Bothwell" title="James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell">James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell</a>, one of the chief murder suspects. A large proportion of the nobility rebelled, resulting ultimately in the imprisonment and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Act_Anent_the_demission_of_the_Crown_in_favour_of_our_Sovereign_Lord,_and_his_Majesty%27s_Coronation_1567&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Act Anent the demission of the Crown in favour of our Sovereign Lord, and his Majesty's Coronation 1567 (page does not exist)">forced abdication</a> of Mary at <a href="/wiki/Loch_Leven_Castle" title="Loch Leven Castle">Loch Leven Castle</a>. She escaped and fled to <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">England</a>, but some of the nobility remained faithful to her cause. Edinburgh Castle was initially handed by its Captain, <a href="/wiki/James_Balfour,_Lord_Pittendreich" title="James Balfour, Lord Pittendreich">James Balfour</a>, to the <a href="/wiki/James_Stewart,_1st_Earl_of_Moray" title="James Stewart, 1st Earl of Moray">Regent Moray</a>, who had forced Mary's abdication and now held power in the name of the infant King James VI. Shortly after the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Langside" title="Battle of Langside">Battle of Langside</a>, in May 1568, Moray appointed <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Kirkcaldy_of_Grange&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Kirkcaldy of Grange (page does not exist)">Sir William Kirkcaldy of Grange</a> Keeper of the Castle.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh_Castle_during_the_%27Lang_Siege%27_(May_1573).jpg" title="File:Edinburgh Castle during the 'Lang Siege' (May 1573).jpg">File:Edinburgh Castle during the 'Lang Siege' (May 1573).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Detail from a contemporary drawing of Edinburgh Castle under siege in 1573, showing it surrounded by attacking batteries</div></div></div>
<p>Grange was a trusted lieutenant of the Regent, but after Moray's murder in January 1570 his allegiance to the King's cause began to waver. <a href="/w/index.php?title=Marian_civil_war&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Marian civil war (page does not exist)">Intermittent civil war</a> continued between the supporters of the two monarchs, and in April 1571 <a href="/wiki/Dumbarton_Castle" title="Dumbarton Castle">Dumbarton Castle</a> fell to "the King's men". Under the influence of <a href="/wiki/William_Maitland_of_Lethington" title="William Maitland of Lethington">William Maitland of Lethington</a>, Mary's secretary, Grange changed sides, occupying the town and castle of Edinburgh for Queen Mary, and against the new regent, the <a href="/wiki/Matthew_Stewart,_4th_Earl_of_Lennox" title="Matthew Stewart, 4th Earl of Lennox">Earl of Lennox</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> The stand-off which followed was not resolved until two years later, and became known as the "Lang Siege", from the <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a> word for "long". Hostilities began in May, with a month-long siege of the town, and a second short siege in October. Blockades and skirmishing continued meanwhile, and Grange continued to refortify the castle. The King's party appealed to <a href="/wiki/Elizabeth_I_of_England" title="Elizabeth I of England">Elizabeth I of England</a> for assistance, as they lacked the artillery and money required to reduce the castle, and feared that Grange would receive aid from France. Elizabeth sent ambassadors to negotiate, and in July 1572 a truce was agreed and the blockade lifted. The town was effectively surrendered to the King's party, with Grange confined to the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup>
</p><p>The truce expired on 1 January 1573, and Grange began bombarding the town. His supplies of powder and shot, however, were running low, and despite having 40 cannon available, there were only seven gunners in the garrison.<sup id="cite_ref-Potter.2C_p.131_65-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Potter.2C_p.131-65">[65]</a></sup> The King's forces, now with the <a href="/wiki/James_Douglas,_4th_Earl_of_Morton" title="James Douglas, 4th Earl of Morton">Earl of Morton</a> in charge as regent, were making headway with plans for a siege. Trenches were dug to surround the castle, and St Margaret's Well was poisoned.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> By February, all Queen Mary's other supporters had surrendered to the Regent, but Grange resolved to resist despite water shortages within the castle. The garrison continued to bombard the town, killing a number of citizens. They also made sorties to set fires, burning 100 houses in the town and then firing on anyone attempting to put out the flames.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:SirWilliamDrury.jpg" title="File:SirWilliamDrury.jpg">File:SirWilliamDrury.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Sir William Drury, commander of Elizabeth I of England's Protestant troops who brought the Lang Siege to an end in 1573. Unknown artist</div></div></div>
<p>In April, a force of around 1,000 English troops, led by <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Drury&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Drury (page does not exist)">Sir William Drury</a>, arrived in Edinburgh. They were followed by 27 cannon from <a href="/wiki/Berwick-upon-Tweed" title="Berwick-upon-Tweed">Berwick-upon-Tweed</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Potter.2C_p.131_65-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Potter.2C_p.131-65">[65]</a></sup> including one that had been cast within Edinburgh Castle and captured by the English at Flodden.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup> The English troops built an artillery emplacement on Castle Hill, immediately facing the east walls of the castle, and five others to the north, west and south. By 17 May these batteries were ready, and the bombardment began. Over the next 12 days the gunners dispatched around 3,000 shots at the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-Potter137_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Potter137-6">[6]</a></sup> On 22 May, the south wall of David's Tower collapsed, and the next day the Constable's Tower also fell. The debris blocked the castle entrance, as well as the Fore Well, although this had already run dry.<sup id="cite_ref-Potter137_6-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Potter137-6">[6]</a></sup> On 26 May, the English attacked and captured the Spur, the outer fortification of the castle, which had been isolated by the collapse. The following day Grange emerged from the castle by a ladder after calling for a ceasefire to allow negotiations for a surrender to take place. When it was made clear that he would not be allowed to go free even if he ended the siege, Grange resolved to continue the resistance, but the garrison threatened to mutiny. He therefore arranged for Drury and his men to enter the castle on 28 May, preferring to surrender to the English rather than the Regent Morton.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> Edinburgh Castle was handed over to George Douglas of Parkhead, the Regent's brother, and the garrison were allowed to go free.<sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> In contrast, Kirkcaldy of Grange, his brother James and two jewellers, James Mossman and James Cokke, who had been minting coins in Mary's name inside the castle, were hanged at the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Mercat_Cross,_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Mercat Cross, Edinburgh (page does not exist)">Cross in Edinburgh</a> on 3 August.<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Nova_Scotia_and_Civil_War">Nova Scotia and Civil War</span></h3>
<p>Much of the castle was subsequently rebuilt by Regent Morton, including the Spur, the new Half Moon Battery and the Portcullis Gate. Some of these works were supervised by <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_MacDowall&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William MacDowall (page does not exist)">William MacDowall</a>, the master of work who fifteen years earlier had repaired David's Tower.<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> The Half Moon Battery, while impressive in size, is considered by historians to have been an ineffective and outdated artillery fortification.<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> This may have been due to a shortage of resources, although the battery's position obscuring the ancient David's Tower and enhancing the prominence of the palace block, has been seen as a significant decision.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>The battered palace block remained unused, particularly after James VI departed to become King of England in 1603.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> James had repairs carried out in 1584, and in 1615–1616 more extensive repairs were carried out in preparation for his return visit to Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> The mason <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Wallace_(mason)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Wallace (mason) (page does not exist)">William Wallace</a> and master of works <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Murray_(architect)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Murray (architect) (page does not exist)">James Murray</a> introduced an early Scottish example of the double-pile block.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup> The principal external features were the three, three-storey <a href="/wiki/Oriel_window" title="Oriel window">oriel windows</a> on the east façade, facing the town and emphasising that this was a palace rather than just a place of defence.<sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> During his visit in 1617, James held court in the refurbished palace block, but still preferred to sleep at Holyrood.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh_Castle_Nova_Scotia.JPG" title="File:Edinburgh Castle Nova Scotia.JPG">File:Edinburgh Castle Nova Scotia.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Memorial plaque to Sir William Alexander, on the Castle Esplanade</div></div></div>
<p>In 1621, King James granted <a href="/wiki/William_Alexander,_1st_Earl_of_Stirling" title="William Alexander, 1st Earl of Stirling">Sir William Alexander</a> the land in <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a> between <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New England (page does not exist)">New England</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Newfoundland_(island)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Newfoundland (island) (page does not exist)">Newfoundland</a>, as <i><a href="/wiki/Nova_Scotia" title="Nova Scotia">Nova Scotia</a></i> ("New Scotland"). To promote the settlement and <a href="/wiki/Plantation" title="Plantation">plantation</a> of the new territory, the <a href="/wiki/Baronetage_of_Nova_Scotia" title="Baronetage of Nova Scotia" class="mw-redirect">Baronetage of Nova Scotia</a> was created in 1624. Under <a href="/wiki/Scots_Law" title="Scots Law" class="mw-redirect">Scots Law</a>, <a href="/wiki/Baronet" title="Baronet">baronets</a> had to "take <a href="/wiki/Sasine" title="Sasine">sasine</a>" by symbolically receiving the earth and stone of the land of which they were baronet. To make this possible, since Nova Scotia was so distant, the King declared that sasine could be taken either in the new province or alternatively "at the castle of Edinburgh as the most eminent and principal place of Scotland."<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup>
</p><p>James' successor, <a href="/wiki/Charles_I_of_England" title="Charles I of England">King Charles I</a>, visited Edinburgh Castle only once, hosting a feast in the Great Hall and staying the night before his Scottish coronation in 1633. This was the last occasion that a reigning monarch resided in the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter47_51-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter47-51">[51]</a></sup> In 1639, in response to Charles' attempts to impose <a href="/wiki/Episcopal_polity" title="Episcopal polity">Episcopacy</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_Scotland" title="Church of Scotland">Scottish Church</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bishops%E2%80%99_Wars&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bishops’ Wars (page does not exist)">civil war</a> broke out between the King's forces and the Presbyterian <a href="/w/index.php?title=Covenanter&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Covenanter (page does not exist)">Covenanters</a>. The Covenanters, led by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Leslie,_1st_Earl_of_Leven" title="Alexander Leslie, 1st Earl of Leven">Alexander Leslie</a>, captured Edinburgh Castle after a short siege, although it was restored to Charles after the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Treaty_of_Berwick_(1639)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Treaty of Berwick (1639) (page does not exist)">Peace of Berwick</a> in June the same year. The peace was short-lived, however, and the following year the Covenanters took the castle again, this time after a three-month siege, during which the garrison ran out of supplies. The Spur was badly damaged, and was demolished in the 1640s.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup> The Royalist commander <a href="/wiki/James_Graham,_1st_Marquess_of_Montrose" title="James Graham, 1st Marquess of Montrose">James Graham, 1st Marquis of Montrose</a> was imprisoned here after his capture in 1650.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter48_79-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter48-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>In May 1650, the Covenanters signed the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Breda_(1650)" title="Treaty of Breda (1650)">Treaty of Breda</a>, allying themselves with the exiled <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">Charles II</a> against the <a href="/wiki/Roundhead" title="Roundhead">English Parliamentarians</a>, who had executed his father the previous year. In response to the Scots proclaiming Charles King, <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Cromwell" title="Oliver Cromwell">Oliver Cromwell</a> launched an invasion of Scotland, defeating the Covenanter army at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Dunbar_(1650)" title="Battle of Dunbar (1650)">Dunbar</a> in September. Edinburgh Castle was taken after a three-month siege, which caused further damage. The Governor of the Castle, Colonel Walter Dundas, surrendered to Cromwell despite having enough supplies to hold out, allegedly from a desire to change sides.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter48_79-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter48-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Garrison_fortress:_Jacobites_and_prisoners_of_war">Garrison fortress: Jacobites and prisoners of war</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Prospect_of_Edinburgh_Castle_from_the_East_(c.1753).jpg" title="File:Prospect of Edinburgh Castle from the East (c.1753).jpg">File:Prospect of Edinburgh Castle from the East (c.1753).jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">An engraving of Edinburgh Castle made shortly before the creation of the Esplanade was begun in 1753</div></div></div>
<p>After his <a href="/w/index.php?title=English_Restoration&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="English Restoration (page does not exist)">Restoration</a> in 1660, Charles II opted to maintain a full-time <a href="/wiki/Standing_army" title="Standing army">standing army</a> based on Cromwell's <a href="/wiki/New_Model_Army" title="New Model Army">New Model Army</a>. From this time until 1923, a garrison was continuously maintained at the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> The medieval royal castle was transformed into a garrison fortress, but continued to see military and political action. The <a href="/wiki/Archibald_Campbell,_1st_Marquess_of_Argyll" title="Archibald Campbell, 1st Marquess of Argyll">Marquis of Argyll</a> was imprisoned here in 1661, when <a href="/wiki/Charles_II_of_England" title="Charles II of England">King Charles II</a> settled old scores with his enemies following his return to the throne. Twenty years later, Argyll's son, the <a href="/wiki/Archibald_Campbell,_9th_Earl_of_Argyll" title="Archibald Campbell, 9th Earl of Argyll">9th Earl of Argyll</a>, was also imprisoned in the castle for religious <a href="/w/index.php?title=Nonconformism&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Nonconformism (page does not exist)">Nonconformism</a> in the reign of <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_II_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James II of England (page does not exist)">King James VII</a>. He escaped by disguising himself as his sister's <a href="/wiki/Footman" title="Footman">footman</a>, but was recaptured and returned to the castle after his failed rebellion to oust James from the throne in 1685.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter48_79-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter48-79">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>James VII was deposed and exiled by the <a href="/wiki/Glorious_Revolution" title="Glorious Revolution">Glorious Revolution</a> of 1688, which installed <a href="/wiki/William_III_of_England" title="William III of England">William of Orange</a> as King of England. Not long after, in early 1689, the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland" title="Parliament of Scotland">Estates of Scotland</a>, after convening to accept William formally as their new king, demanded that <a href="/wiki/George_Gordon,_1st_Duke_of_Gordon" title="George Gordon, 1st Duke of Gordon">Duke of Gordon</a>, Governor of the Castle, surrender the fortress. Gordon, who had been appointed by James VII as a fellow Catholic, refused. In March 1689, the castle was blockaded by 7,000 troops against a garrison of 160 men, further weakened by religious disputes. On 18 March, <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Graham,_1st_Viscount_of_Dundee&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Graham, 1st Viscount of Dundee (page does not exist)">Viscount Dundee</a>, intent on raising a rebellion in the Highlands, climbed up the western side of the Castle Rock to urge Gordon to hold the castle against the new King.<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> Gordon agreed, but during the ensuing siege he refused to fire upon the town, while the besiegers inflicted little damage on the castle. Despite Dundee's initial successes in the north, Gordon eventually surrendered on 14 June, due to dwindling supplies and having lost 70 men during the three-month siege.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> Under the terms of the <a href="/wiki/Acts_of_Union_1707" title="Acts of Union 1707">Acts of Union</a>, which joined England and Scotland in 1707, Edinburgh was one of the four Scottish castles to be maintained and permanently garrisoned by the new <a href="/wiki/British_Army" title="British Army">British Army</a>, the others being <a href="/wiki/Stirling_Castle" title="Stirling Castle">Stirling</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dumbarton_Castle" title="Dumbarton Castle">Dumbarton</a> and <a href="/wiki/Blackness_Castle" title="Blackness Castle">Blackness</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinpain.JPG" title="File:Edinpain.JPG">File:Edinpain.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><i>Edinburgh Castle with the Nor Loch in foreground</i>, around 1780, by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Nasmyth" title="Alexander Nasmyth">Alexander Nasmyth</a></div></div></div>
<p>The castle was almost taken in the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jacobite_Rising_of_1715&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jacobite Rising of 1715 (page does not exist)">first Jacobite rising</a> in support of <a href="/wiki/James_Francis_Edward_Stuart" title="James Francis Edward Stuart">James Stuart</a>, the "Old Pretender", in 1715. On 8 September, just two days after the rising began, a party of around 100 Jacobite Highlanders, led by <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_Drummond,_2nd_Duke_of_Perth&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James Drummond, 2nd Duke of Perth (page does not exist)">Lord Drummond</a>, attempted to scale the walls with the assistance of members of the garrison. However, the rope ladder lowered by the castle sentries was too short, and the alarm was raised after a change of the watch. The Jacobites fled, while the deserters within the castle were hanged or flogged.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> In 1728, <a href="/wiki/George_Wade" title="George Wade">General Wade</a> reported that the castle's defences were decayed and inadequate,<sup id="cite_ref-Salter48_79-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter48-79">[79]</a></sup> and a major strengthening of the defences was carried out throughout the 1720s and 1730s. This was the period when most of the artillery defences and <a href="/wiki/Bastion" title="Bastion">bastions</a> on the north and west sides of the castle were built. These were designed by military engineer Captain <a href="/w/index.php?title=John_Lambertus_Romer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="John Lambertus Romer (page does not exist)">John Romer</a>, and built by the architect <a href="/wiki/William_Adam_(architect)" title="William Adam (architect)">William Adam</a>. They include the Argyle Battery, Mills Mount Battery, the Low Defences and the Western Defences.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>The last military action at the castle took place during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Jacobite_Rising_of_1745&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Jacobite Rising of 1745 (page does not exist)">second Jacobite rising</a> of 1745. The Jacobite army, under <a href="/wiki/Charles_Edward_Stuart" title="Charles Edward Stuart">Charles Edward Stuart</a> ("Bonnie Prince Charlie"), captured Edinburgh without a fight in September 1745, but the castle remained in the hands of its ageing Deputy Governor, General <a href="/w/index.php?title=George_Preston&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="George Preston (page does not exist)">George Preston</a>, who refused to surrender.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup> After their victory over the government army at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Prestonpans" title="Battle of Prestonpans">Prestonpans</a> on 21 September, the Jacobites attempted to blockade the castle. Preston's response was to bombard Jacobite positions within the town. After several buildings had been demolished and four people killed, Charles called off the blockade.<sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> The Jacobites themselves had no heavy guns with which to respond, and by November they had marched into England, leaving Edinburgh to the castle garrison.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>Over the next century, the castle vaults were used to hold prisoners of war during several conflicts, including the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Seven_Years%27_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Seven Years' War (page does not exist)">Seven Years' War</a> (1756–1763), the <a href="/wiki/American_War_of_Independence" title="American War of Independence" class="mw-redirect">American War of Independence</a> (1775–1783) and the <a href="/wiki/Napoleonic_Wars" title="Napoleonic Wars">Napoleonic Wars</a> (1803–1815).<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> During this time, several new buildings were erected within the castle, including powder magazines, stores, the Governor's House (1742),<sup id="cite_ref-92" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-92">[92]</a></sup> and the New Barracks (1796–1799).<sup id="cite_ref-93" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-93">[93]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="19th_century_to_the_present">19th century to the present</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:KGIV_and_hat.jpg" title="File:KGIV and hat.jpg">File:KGIV and hat.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">King George IV waves from the battlements of the Half Moon Battery in 1822, drawn by James Skene</div></div></div>
<p>A mass prison break in 1811, in which 49 prisoners of war escaped via a hole in the south wall, persuaded the authorities that the castle vaults were no longer suitable as a prison. This use ceased in 1814<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup> and the castle began gradually to assume a different role as a national monument. In 1818, <a href="/wiki/Walter_Scott" title="Walter Scott">Sir Walter Scott</a> was given permission to search the castle for the <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Scotland" title="Crown of Scotland">Crown of Scotland</a>, believed lost after the union of Scotland and England in 1707. Breaking into  a sealed room, now known as the Crown Room, and unlocking a chest within, he rediscovered the <a href="/wiki/Honours_of_Scotland" title="Honours of Scotland">Honours of Scotland</a>, which were then put on public display with an entry charge of one <a href="/wiki/Shilling" title="Shilling">shilling</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham60_95-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham60-95">[95]</a></sup> In 1822, <a href="/wiki/George_IV_of_England" title="George IV of England" class="mw-redirect">King George IV</a> made a <a href="/wiki/Visit_of_King_George_IV_to_Scotland" title="Visit of King George IV to Scotland">visit to Edinburgh</a>, becoming the first reigning monarch to visit the castle since Charles II in 1651. In 1829, the cannon Mons Meg was returned from the Tower of London, where it had been taken as part of the process of disarming Scotland after "the '45", and the palace began to be opened up to visitors during the 1830s.<sup id="cite_ref-MacIvor107_96-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacIvor107-96">[96]</a></sup> St Margaret's Chapel was "rediscovered" in 1845, having been used as a store for many years.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham60_95-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham60-95">[95]</a></sup> Works in the 1880s, funded by the Edinburgh publisher William Nelson and carried out by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hippolyte_Blanc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hippolyte Blanc (page does not exist)">Hippolyte Blanc</a>, saw the Argyle Tower built over the Portcullis Gate and the Great Hall restored after years of use as a barracks.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup> A new Gatehouse was built in 1888. During the 19th century, several schemes were put forward for rebuilding the whole castle as a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_baronial_style&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish baronial style (page does not exist)">Scottish Baronial</a> style <i>château</i>. Work began in 1858, but was soon abandoned, and only the hospital building was eventually remodelled in 1897.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup> Following the death of <a href="/wiki/Albert,_Prince_Consort" title="Albert, Prince Consort">Prince Albert</a> in 1861, the architect <a href="/wiki/David_Bryce" title="David Bryce">David Bryce</a> put forward a proposal for a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> keep as a memorial, but <a href="/w/index.php?title=Victoria_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Victoria of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Queen Victoria</a> objected and the scheme was not pursued.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Soldiers_of_the_Castle_garrison,_c.1845.jpg" title="File:Soldiers of the Castle garrison, c.1845.jpg">File:Soldiers of the Castle garrison, c.1845.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Soldiers of the castle garrison in an early photograph c.1845</div></div></div>
<p>In 1905, responsibility for the castle was transferred from the <a href="/wiki/War_Office" title="War Office">War Office</a> to the <a href="/wiki/Office_of_Works" title="Office of Works">Office of Works</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> although the garrison remained until 1923, when the troops moved to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Redford_Barracks&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Redford Barracks (page does not exist)">Redford Barracks</a> in south-west Edinburgh. The castle was again used as a prison during the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War" class="mw-redirect">First World War</a>, when "<a href="/wiki/Red_Clydeside" title="Red Clydeside">Red Clydesider</a>" <a href="/wiki/David_Kirkwood" title="David Kirkwood">David Kirkwood</a> was confined in the military prison block, and during the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Second_World_War&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Second World War (page does not exist)">Second World War</a>, when downed German <i>Luftwaffe</i> pilots were captured.<sup id="cite_ref-99" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-99">[99]</a></sup> The position of <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Governors_of_Edinburgh_Castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Governors of Edinburgh Castle (page does not exist)">Governor of Edinburgh Castle</a>, vacant since 1876, was revived in 1935 as an honorary title for the <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_Officer_Commanding&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="General Officer Commanding (page does not exist)">General Officer Commanding</a> in Scotland, the first holder being Lieutenant-General Sir Archibald Cameron of Lochiel.<sup id="cite_ref-100" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-100">[100]</a></sup> The castle passed into the care of <a href="/wiki/Historic_Scotland" title="Historic Scotland">Historic Scotland</a> when it was established in 1991, and was designated a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scheduled_Ancient_Monument&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scheduled Ancient Monument (page does not exist)">Scheduled Ancient Monument</a> in 1993.<sup id="cite_ref-101" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-101">[101]</a></sup> The buildings and structures of the castle are further protected by 24 separate <a href="/w/index.php?title=Listed_building&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Listed building (page does not exist)">listings</a>, including 13 at <a href="/w/index.php?title=Category_A_listed&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Category A listed (page does not exist)">category A</a>, the highest level of protection for a historic building in Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-102" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-102">[102]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Town,_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Town, Edinburgh (page does not exist)">Old</a> and <a href="/w/index.php?title=New_Town,_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="New Town, Edinburgh (page does not exist)">New Towns of Edinburgh</a>, a <a href="/w/index.php?title=World_Heritage_Sites_in_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="World Heritage Sites in the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">World Heritage Site</a> inscribed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=UNESCO&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="UNESCO (page does not exist)">UNESCO</a> in 1995, is described as "dominated by a medieval fortress".<sup id="cite_ref-103" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-103">[103]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Description">Description</span></h2>
<p>Edinburgh Castle is located at the top of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Mile" title="Royal Mile">Royal Mile</a>, at the west end of Edinburgh's <a href="/w/index.php?title=Old_Town,_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Old Town, Edinburgh (page does not exist)">Old Town</a>. The volcanic Castle Rock offers a naturally defended position, with sheer cliffs to north and south, and a steep ascent from the west. The only easy approach is from the town to the east, and the castle's defences are situated accordingly, with a series of gates protecting the route to the summit of the Castle Rock.<sup id="cite_ref-104" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-104">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
