<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Outer_defences">Outer defences</span></h3>
<p>In front of the castle is a long sloping forecourt known as the Esplanade. Originally the Spur, a 16th-century <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hornwork&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hornwork (page does not exist)">hornwork</a>, was located here. The present Esplanade was laid out as a parade ground in 1753, and extended in 1845.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup> It is upon this Esplanade that the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edinburgh_Military_Tattoo&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edinburgh Military Tattoo (page does not exist)">Edinburgh Military Tattoo</a> takes place annually. From the Esplanade the Half Moon Battery is prominent, with the Royal Palace to its left.<sup id="cite_ref-MacIvor136_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacIvor136-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Gatehouse&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Gatehouse (page does not exist)">Gatehouse</a> at the head of the Esplanade was built as an architecturally cosmetic addition to the castle in 1888.<sup id="cite_ref-106" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-106">[106]</a></sup> Statues of <a href="/wiki/Robert_the_Bruce" title="Robert the Bruce">Robert the Bruce</a> by Thomas Clapperton and <a href="/wiki/William_Wallace" title="William Wallace">William Wallace</a> by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Alexander_Carrick&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Alexander Carrick (page does not exist)">Alexander Carrick</a> were added in 1929, and the <a href="/wiki/Latin" title="Latin">Latin</a> motto <i><a href="/wiki/Nemo_me_impune_lacessit" title="Nemo me impune lacessit">Nemo me impune lacessit</a></i> is inscribed above the gate. The dry ditch in front of the entrance was completed in its present form in 1742.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> Within the Gatehouse are offices, and to the north is the most recent addition to the castle; the ticket office, completed in 2008 to a design by Gareth Hoskins Architects.<sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> The road, built by James III in 1464 for the transport of cannon, leads upward and around to the north of the Half Moon Battery and the Forewall Battery, to the Portcullis Gate. In 1990, an alternative access was opened by digging a tunnel from the north of the esplanade to the north-west part of the castle, separating visitor traffic from service traffic.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh_Castle_Portcullis_Gate.jpg" title="File:Edinburgh Castle Portcullis Gate.jpg">File:Edinburgh Castle Portcullis Gate.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Portcullis Gate</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Portcullis_Gate_and_Argyle_Tower">Portcullis Gate and Argyle Tower</span></h3>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Portcullis" title="Portcullis">Portcullis</a> Gate was begun by the Regent Morton after the Lang Siege of 1571–73 to replace the round Constable's Tower, which was destroyed in the siege.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> In 1584 the upper parts of the Gatehouse were completed by <a href="/w/index.php?title=William_Schaw&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="William Schaw (page does not exist)">William Schaw</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> and these were further modified in 1750.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> In 1886–1887 this plain building was replaced with a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scots_Baronial_Style_architecture&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scots Baronial Style architecture (page does not exist)">Scots Baronial</a> tower, designed by the architect <a href="/w/index.php?title=Hippolyte_Blanc&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hippolyte Blanc (page does not exist)">Hippolyte Blanc</a>, although the original Portcullis Gate remains below. The new structure was named the Argyle Tower, from the fact that the 9th Earl of Argyll had been held here prior to his execution in 1685.<sup id="cite_ref-MI114_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI114-113">[113]</a></sup> Described as "restoration in an extreme form",<sup id="cite_ref-MI114_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI114-113">[113]</a></sup> the rebuilding of the Argyle Tower was the first in a series of works funded by the publisher William Nelson.<sup id="cite_ref-MI114_113-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI114-113">[113]</a></sup>
</p><p>Just inside the gate is the Argyle Battery overlooking <a href="/wiki/Princes_Street" title="Princes Street">Princes Street</a>, with Mills Mount Battery, the location of the One O'Clock Gun, to the west. Below these is the Low Defence, while at the base of the rock is the ruined Wellhouse Tower, built in 1362 to guard St. Margaret's Well.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> This natural spring provided an important secondary source of water for the castle, the water being lifted up by a crane mounted on a platform known as the Crane Bastion.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_buildings">Military buildings</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_New_Barracks,_Edinburgh_Castle.JPG" title="File:The New Barracks, Edinburgh Castle.JPG">File:The New Barracks, Edinburgh Castle.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The New Barracks</div></div></div>
<p>The areas to the north and west of the Argyle Tower are largely occupied by military buildings erected after the castle became a major garrison in the early 18th century.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Adjacent to Mills Mount are the 18th-century cart sheds, now tea rooms.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> The Governor's House to the south was built in 1742 as accommodation for the Governor, Storekeeper, and Master Gunner,<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup> and was used until the post of Governor became vacant in the later 19th century; it was then used by nurses of the castle hospital. Today, it functions as an officers' <a href="/wiki/Mess" title="Mess">mess</a>, and as the office of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=List_of_Governors_of_Edinburgh_Castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="List of Governors of Edinburgh Castle (page does not exist)">Governor</a> since the restoration of the post in 1936.<sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup>
</p><p>South of the Governor's House are the New Barracks, completed in 1799 to house 600 soldiers, and replacing the outdated accommodation in the Great Hall. They now house the Regimental Headquarters of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Regiment_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Regiment of Scotland (page does not exist)">Royal Regiment of Scotland</a> and the Regimental Headquarters and <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regimental_museum&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regimental museum (page does not exist)">Museum</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scots_Dragoon_Guards" title="Royal Scots Dragoon Guards">Royal Scots Dragoon Guards (Carabiniers and Greys)</a>. The latter was opened in 1995 by the regiment's Colonel, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Elizabeth_II_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Queen Elizabeth II</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> Also nearby, in the former Royal Scots <a href="/wiki/Drill_hall" title="Drill hall">drill hall</a>, constructed in 1900, is the regimental museum of the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scots" title="Royal Scots">Royal Scots (The Royal Regiment)</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Military_prison" title="Military prison">military prison</a> was built in 1842 as a detention block for the castle garrison and was extended in the 1880s. It was last used in 1923, when the garrison moved to the city's Redford Barracks.<sup id="cite_ref-MacIvor107_96-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacIvor107-96">[96]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="National_War_Museum_of_Scotland">National War Museum of Scotland</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p><p>West of the Governor's House, a store for munitions was built in 1747–48 and later extended to form a courtyard, in which the main gunpowder magazine also stood.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> In 1897 the area was remodelled as a military hospital, formerly housed in the Great Hall. The building to the south of this courtyard is now the National War Museum of Scotland, which forms part of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Museums_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Museums of Scotland (page does not exist)">National Museums of Scotland</a>. It was formerly known as the Scottish United Services Museum, and, prior to this, the Scottish Naval and Military Museum, when it was located in the <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Castle#Queen_Anne_Building" title="Edinburgh Castle">Queen Anne Building</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> It covers <a href="/w/index.php?title=Military_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Military of Scotland (page does not exist)">Scotland's military history</a> over the past 400 years, and includes a wide range of military artefacts, such as uniforms, medals and weapons. The exhibits also illustrate the history and causes behind the many wars in which Scottish soldiers have been involved. Beside the museum is Butts Battery, named after the <a href="/wiki/Archery" title="Archery">archery</a> butts (targets) formerly placed here.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> Below it are the Western Defences, where a <a href="/wiki/Postern" title="Postern">postern</a>, named the West Sally Port, gives access to the western slope of the rock.<sup id="cite_ref-124" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-124">[124]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Upper_Ward">Upper Ward</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:One_of_the_paths_leading_to_St._Margaret%27s_Chapel.jpg" title="File:One of the paths leading to St. Margaret's Chapel.jpg">File:One of the paths leading to St. Margaret's Chapel.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Foog's Gate</div></div></div>
<p>The Upper Ward or Citadel occupies the highest part of the Castle Rock, and is entered via the late 17th-century Foog's Gate.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> The origin of this name is unknown, although it was formerly known as the Foggy Gate, which may relate to the dense sea-fogs, known as <a href="/w/index.php?title=Haar_(fog)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Haar (fog) (page does not exist)">haars</a>, which commonly affect Edinburgh.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> Adjacent to the gates are the large cisterns built to reduce the castle's dependency on well water and a former fire station, now used as a shop. The summit of the rock is occupied by St Margaret's Chapel and 15th-century siege gun Mons Meg. On a ledge below this area is a small 19th-century Dogs' Cemetery for the burial of the soldiers' <a href="/w/index.php?title=Regimental_mascot&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Regimental mascot (page does not exist)">regimental mascots</a>. Beside this, the Lang Stair leads down to the Argyle Battery, past a section of a medieval bastion,<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> and gives access to the upper storey of the Argyle Tower. The eastern end of the Upper Ward is occupied by the Forewall and Half Moon Batteries, with Crown Square to the south.<sup id="cite_ref-MacIvor136_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MacIvor136-105">[105]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:St_Margarets_Chapel.JPG" title="File:St Margarets Chapel.JPG">File:St Margarets Chapel.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">St. Margaret's Chapel</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="St._Margaret.27s_Chapel">St. Margaret's Chapel</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The oldest building in the castle, and in Edinburgh, is the small St. Margaret's Chapel.<sup id="cite_ref-eotca_1-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-eotca-1">[1]</a></sup> One of the few 12th-century structures surviving in any Scottish castle,<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.23_37-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.23-37">[37]</a></sup> it dates from the reign of <a href="/wiki/David_I_of_Scotland" title="David I of Scotland">King David I</a> (r.1124–1153), who built it as a private chapel for the royal family and dedicated it to his mother, <a href="/wiki/Saint_Margaret_of_Scotland" title="Saint Margaret of Scotland">Saint Margaret of Scotland</a>, who died in the castle in 1093. It survived the slighting of 1314, when the castle's defences were destroyed on the orders of Robert the Bruce, and was used as a gunpowder store from the 16th century, when the present roof was built. In 1845, it was "discovered" by the <a href="/wiki/Antiquary" title="Antiquary" class="mw-redirect">antiquary</a> <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Wilson_(academic)" title="Daniel Wilson (academic)">Daniel Wilson</a>, while in use as part of the larger garrison chapel, and was restored in 1851–1852.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup> The chapel is still used for religious ceremonies, such as weddings.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup>  <br style="clear:both;" />
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Mons_Meg">Mons Meg</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Mons_Meg,_Medieval_Bombard,_Edinburgh,_Scotland._Pic_01.jpg" title="File:Mons Meg, Medieval Bombard, Edinburgh, Scotland. Pic 01.jpg">File:Mons Meg, Medieval Bombard, Edinburgh, Scotland. Pic 01.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The siege gun Mons Meg described in a 17thC document as "the great iron murderer called Muckle-Meg" (<i>muckle</i> being <a href="/wiki/Scots_language" title="Scots language">Scots</a> for 'big')</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
The 15th-century siege gun or <a href="/w/index.php?title=Bombard_(weapon)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Bombard (weapon) (page does not exist)">bombard</a> known as Mons Meg is displayed on a terrace in front of St. Margaret's Chapel. She was constructed in <a href="/wiki/Flanders" title="Flanders">Flanders</a> on the orders of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Philip_III,_Duke_of_Burgundy&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Philip III, Duke of Burgundy (page does not exist)">Philip III, Duke of Burgundy</a> in 1449, and gifted by him to the husband of his niece, King <a href="/wiki/James_II_of_Scotland" title="James II of Scotland">James II</a>, in 1457.<sup id="cite_ref-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.76_52-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tabraham_1997.2C_p.76-52">[52]</a></sup> The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> gun rests on a reconstructed carriage, the details of which were copied from an old stone relief that can be seen inside the tunnel of the Gatehouse at the castle entrance. Some of Meg's large gun stones, weighing around <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> each,<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> are displayed alongside her. On 3 July 1558, she was fired in salute to celebrate the marriage of <a href="/wiki/Mary,_Queen_of_Scots" title="Mary, Queen of Scots">Mary, Queen of Scots</a> to the French <a href="/wiki/Dauphin_of_France" title="Dauphin of France">dauphin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_II" title="François II" class="mw-redirect">François II</a>. The royal Treasurer's Accounts of the time record a payment to soldiers for retrieving one of her stones from <a href="/w/index.php?title=Trinity,_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Trinity, Edinburgh (page does not exist)">Wardie Muir</a> near the <a href="/wiki/River_Forth" title="River Forth">River Forth</a>, fully <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> from the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-128" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-128">[128]</a></sup> The gun has been defunct since her barrel burst while firing a salute to greet the Duke of Albany, the future <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_II_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James II of England (page does not exist)">King James VII and II</a>, on his arrival in Edinburgh on 30 October 1681.<sup id="cite_ref-129" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-129">[129]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Half_Moon_Battery_and_David.27s_Tower">Half Moon Battery and David's Tower</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Half_Moon_Battery_and_Palace_Block,_Edinburgh_Castle.jpg" title="File:Half Moon Battery and Palace Block, Edinburgh Castle.jpg">File:Half Moon Battery and Palace Block, Edinburgh Castle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Half Moon Battery and Palace Block seen from the Esplanade</div></div></div>
<p>The Half Moon Battery, which remains a prominent feature on the east side of the castle, was built as part of the reconstruction works supervised by the <a href="/wiki/James_Douglas,_4th_Earl_of_Morton" title="James Douglas, 4th Earl of Morton">Regent Morton</a>, and was erected between 1573 and 1588.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> The Forewall to the north was built between 1689 and 1695 to link the Half Moon to the Portcullis Tower, although part of the original wall of 1540 was incorporated into it.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> The Half Moon Battery was built around and over the ruins of David's Tower, two storeys of which survive beneath, with windows facing out onto the interior wall of the battery. David's Tower was built on an <a href="/w/index.php?title=L-plan_castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="L-plan castle (page does not exist)">L-plan</a>, the main block being <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, with a wing measuring <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> to the west.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> The entrance was via a pointed-arched doorway in the inner angle, although in the 16th century this was filled in to make the tower a solid rectangle. Prior to the Lang Siege, the tower was recorded as being <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> high, and the remaining portions stand up to <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> from the rock.<sup id="cite_ref-Oldrieve_130-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oldrieve-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Artefacts_from_David%27s_Tower,_Edinburgh_Castle.jpg" title="File:Artefacts from David's Tower, Edinburgh Castle.jpg">File:Artefacts from David's Tower, Edinburgh Castle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Artefacts found during excavation of David's Tower</div></div></div>
<p>The tower was rediscovered during routine maintenance work in 1912, and excavations below the Half Moon Battery revealed the extent of the surviving buildings. Several rooms are accessible to the public, although the lower parts are generally closed. Outside the tower, but within the battery, is a three-storey room, where large portions of the exterior wall of the tower are still visible, showing shattered masonry caused by the bombardment of 1573.<sup id="cite_ref-Oldrieve_130-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oldrieve-130">[130]</a></sup> Beside the tower, a section of the former <a href="/w/index.php?title=Curtain_wall_(fortification)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Curtain wall (fortification) (page does not exist)">curtain wall</a> was discovered, with a gun loop which overlooked the High Street: a recess was made in the outer battery wall to reveal this gun loop. Also in 1912–1913, the adjacent Fore Well was cleared and surveyed, and was found to be <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> deep, and mostly hewn through the rock below the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-Oldrieve_130-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Oldrieve-130">[130]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Crown_Square">Crown Square</span></h3>
<p>Crown Square, also known as Palace Yard, was laid out in the 15th century, during the reign of <a href="/wiki/James_III_of_Scotland" title="James III of Scotland">King James III</a>, as the principal courtyard of the castle. The foundations were formed by the construction of a series of large stone <a href="/w/index.php?title=Vault_(architecture)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Vault (architecture) (page does not exist)">vaults</a> built onto the uneven Castle Rock in the 1430s. These vaults were used as a state prison until the 19th century, although more important prisoners were held in the main parts of the castle.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup> The square is formed by the Royal Palace to the east, the Great Hall to the south, the Queen Anne Building to the west, and the National War Memorial to the north.<sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh-Castle.jpg" title="File:Edinburgh-Castle.jpg">File:Edinburgh-Castle.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Royal Palace in Crown Square</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Royal_Palace">Royal Palace</span></h4>
<p>The Royal Palace comprises the former royal apartments, which were the residence of the later <a href="/wiki/House_of_Stuart" title="House of Stuart">Stewart</a> monarchs. It was begun in the mid 15th century, during the reign of <a href="/wiki/James_IV_of_Scotland" title="James IV of Scotland">James IV</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> and it originally communicated with David's Tower.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> The building was extensively remodelled for the visit of <a href="/w/index.php?title=James_I_of_England&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="James I of England (page does not exist)">James VI</a> to the castle in 1617, when <a href="/wiki/State_apartment" title="State apartment" class="mw-redirect">state apartments</a> for the King and Queen were built.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> On the ground floor is the Laich (low) Hall, now called the King's Dining Room, and a small room, known as the Birth Chamber or Mary Room, where James VI was born to Mary, Queen of Scots, in June 1566. The commemorative <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_Renaissance_painted_ceilings&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish Renaissance painted ceilings (page does not exist)">painted ceiling</a> and other decoration were added in 1617. On the first floor is the vaulted Crown Room, built in 1615 to house the <a href="/wiki/Honours_of_Scotland" title="Honours of Scotland">Honours of Scotland</a>: the <a href="/wiki/Crown_of_Scotland" title="Crown of Scotland">crown</a>, the sceptre and the sword of state.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Stone_of_Scone" title="Stone of Scone">Stone of Scone</a>, upon which the monarchs of Scotland were traditionally crowned, has been kept in the Crown Room since its return to Scotland in 1996. To the south of the palace is the Register House, built in the 1540s to accommodate state archives.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Great_Hall">Great Hall</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:The_Great_Hall,_Edinburgh_Castle_-_geograph.org.uk_-_1299970.jpg" title="File:The Great Hall, Edinburgh Castle - geograph.org.uk - 1299970.jpg">File:The Great Hall, Edinburgh Castle - geograph.org.uk - 1299970.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Interior of the Great Hall</div></div></div>
<p>The Great Hall measures <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>, and was the chief place of state assembly in the castle, although there is no evidence that the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Scotland" title="Parliament of Scotland">Parliament of Scotland</a> ever met here, as is sometimes reported.<sup id="cite_ref-MIhall_137-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MIhall-137">[137]</a></sup> Historians have disagreed over its dating, although it is usually ascribed to the reign of <a href="/wiki/James_IV_of_Scotland" title="James IV of Scotland">King James IV</a>, and is thought to have been completed in the early years of the 16th century.<sup id="cite_ref-138" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-138">[138]</a></sup> The decorative carved stone <a href="/wiki/Corbel" title="Corbel">corbels</a> supporting the roof have <a href="/wiki/Renaissance" title="Renaissance">Renaissance</a> detailing, which has been compared to works at <a href="/wiki/Ch%C3%A2teau_de_Blois" title="Château de Blois">Blois</a>, France, of around 1515, indicating that the arts in Scotland were relatively advanced at this time.<sup id="cite_ref-MIhall_137-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MIhall-137">[137]</a></sup> It is one of only two medieval halls in Scotland with an original <a href="/wiki/Hammerbeam_roof" title="Hammerbeam roof">hammerbeam roof</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup>
</p><p>Following <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Cromwell" title="Oliver Cromwell">Oliver Cromwell</a>'s seizure of the castle in 1650, the Great Hall was converted into a barracks for his troops; and in 1737 it was subdivided into three storeys to house 312 soldiers.<sup id="cite_ref-BoS85-86_49-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BoS85-86-49">[49]</a></sup> Following the construction of the New Barracks in the 1790s, it became a military hospital until 1897. It was then restored by Hippolyte Blanc in line with contemporary ideas of medieval architecture.<sup id="cite_ref-MI114_113-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-MI114-113">[113]</a></sup> The Great Hall is still occasionally used for ceremonial occasions, and has been used as a venue on <a href="/wiki/Hogmanay" title="Hogmanay">Hogmanay</a> for <a href="/wiki/BBC_Scotland" title="BBC Scotland">BBC Scotland</a>'s <i><a href="/w/index.php?title=Hogmanay_Live&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Hogmanay Live (page does not exist)">Hogmanay Live</a></i> programme. To the south of the hall is a section of curtain wall from the 14th century with a parapet of later date.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh_Castle_buildings.JPG" title="File:Edinburgh Castle buildings.JPG">File:Edinburgh Castle buildings.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Queen Anne Building (centre-right)</div></div></div>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Queen_Anne_Building">Queen Anne Building</span></h4>
<p>In the 16th century, this area housed the kitchens serving the adjacent Great Hall, and was later the site of the Royal Gunhouse.<sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> The present building was named after <a href="/wiki/Anne,_Queen_of_Great_Britain" title="Anne, Queen of Great Britain">Queen Anne</a> and was built during the attempted <a href="/w/index.php?title=Planned_French_Invasion_of_Britain_(1708)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Planned French Invasion of Britain (1708) (page does not exist)">Jacobite invasion</a> by the <a href="/wiki/James_Francis_Edward_Stuart" title="James Francis Edward Stuart">Old Pretender</a> in 1708. It was designed by Captain Theodore Dury, military engineer for Scotland, who also designed Dury's Battery, named in his honour, on the south side of the castle in 1713.<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> The Queen Anne Building provided accommodation for <a href="/wiki/Staff_Officer" title="Staff Officer" class="mw-redirect">Staff Officers</a>, but after the departure of the Army it was remodelled in the 1920s as the Naval and Military Museum, to complement the newly opened <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_National_War_Memorial&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish National War Memorial (page does not exist)">Scottish National War Memorial</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-Salter49_107-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Salter49-107">[107]</a></sup> The museum later moved to the former hospital in the western part of the castle, and the building now houses a function suite and an education centre.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Scottish_National_War_Memorial">Scottish National War Memorial</span></h4>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:EdinburghSNWM.JPG" title="File:EdinburghSNWM.JPG">File:EdinburghSNWM.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The Scottish National War Memorial</div></div></div>
<p>The Scottish National War Memorial occupies a converted barrack block on the north side of Crown Square. It stands on the site of the medieval St. Mary's Church which was rebuilt in 1366, and was converted into an armoury in 1540. It was demolished in 1755, and the masonry reused to build a new North Barrack Block on the site.<sup id="cite_ref-143" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-143">[143]</a></sup> Proposals for a Scottish National War Memorial were put forward in 1917, during the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War" class="mw-redirect">First World War</a>, and the architect <a href="/w/index.php?title=Robert_Lorimer&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Robert Lorimer (page does not exist)">Sir Robert Lorimer</a> was appointed in 1919. Construction began in 1923, and the memorial was formally opened on 14 July 1927 by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edward_VIII_of_the_United_Kingdom&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edward VIII of the United Kingdom (page does not exist)">Prince of Wales</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-snwmhist_144-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-snwmhist-144">[144]</a></sup> The exterior is decorated with <a href="/wiki/Gargoyle" title="Gargoyle">gargoyles</a> and sculpture, while the interior contains monuments to individual regiments. The <a href="/wiki/Stained-glass" title="Stained-glass" class="mw-redirect">stained-glass</a> windows are by <a href="/w/index.php?title=Douglas_Strachan&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Douglas Strachan (page does not exist)">Douglas Strachan</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>The memorial commemorates Scottish soldiers, and those serving with <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_regiment&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish regiment (page does not exist)">Scottish regiments</a>, who died in the two world wars and in more recent conflicts. Upon the altar within the Shrine, placed upon the highest point of the Castle Rock, is a sealed casket containing Rolls of Honour which list over 147,000 names of those soldiers killed in the <a href="/wiki/First_World_War" title="First World War" class="mw-redirect">First World War</a>. After the Second World War, another 50,000 names were inscribed on Rolls of Honour held within the Hall, and further names continue to be added there.<sup id="cite_ref-snwmhist_144-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-snwmhist-144">[144]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> The memorial is maintained by a charitable trust.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Present_use">Present use</span></h2>
<p>Edinburgh Castle is in the ownership of the Scottish Ministers as heads of the devolved <a href="/wiki/Scottish_Government" title="Scottish Government">Scottish Government</a>. The castle is run and administered, for the most part, by <a href="/wiki/Historic_Scotland" title="Historic Scotland">Historic Scotland</a>, an <a href="/w/index.php?title=Executive_agency&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Executive agency (page does not exist)">executive agency</a> of the Scottish Government, although the Army remains responsible for some areas, including the New Barracks block and the military museums. Both Historic Scotland and the Army share use of the Guardroom immediately inside the castle entrance.<sup id="cite_ref-osowska_148-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-osowska-148">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:James_Hepburn,_4th_Earl_of_Bothwell.jpg" title="File:James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell.jpg">File:James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">A re-enactor portraying <a href="/wiki/James_Hepburn,_4th_Earl_of_Bothwell" title="James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell">James Hepburn, 4th Earl of Bothwell</a>, a husband of Mary, Queen of Scots, in the Great Hall</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Tourist_attraction">Tourist attraction</span></h3>
<p>Historic Scotland undertakes the dual tasks of operating the castle as a commercially viable <a href="/wiki/Tourism_in_Scotland" title="Tourism in Scotland">tourist attraction</a>, while simultaneously bearing responsibility for conservation of the site. Edinburgh Castle remains the most popular paid visitor attraction in Scotland, with over 1.2 million visitors in 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-ALVA_2-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ALVA-2">[2]</a></sup> Historic Scotland maintains a number of facilities within the castle, including two cafés/restaurants, several shops, and numerous historical displays. An educational centre in the Queen Anne Building runs events for schools and educational groups, and employs <a href="/wiki/Historical_reenactment" title="Historical reenactment">re-enactors</a> in costume and with period weaponry.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_role">Military role</span></h3>
<p>Direct administration of the castle by the <a href="/wiki/War_Office" title="War Office">War Office</a> came to an end in 1905, and in 1923 the Army formally moved to the city's new Redford Barracks. Nevertheless, the castle continues to have a strong connection with the Army, and is one of the few ancient castles in Britain that still has a military garrison, albeit for largely ceremonial and administrative purposes. Public duties performed by the garrison include guarding the <a href="/wiki/Honours_of_Scotland" title="Honours of Scotland">Honours of Scotland</a>, and armed <a href="http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/sentry" class="extiw" title="wikt:sentry">sentries</a> stand watch at the Gatehouse outside opening hours. The post of <a href="/w/index.php?title=Governor_of_Edinburgh_Castle&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Governor of Edinburgh Castle (page does not exist)">Governor of Edinburgh Castle</a> is now a ceremonial post, held by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=General_Officer_Commanding_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="General Officer Commanding Scotland (page does not exist)">General Officer Commanding Scotland</a>. The New Barracks contain both the Governor's House, which serves as the Officers' Mess, and the Regimental Headquarters of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Regiment_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Regiment of Scotland (page does not exist)">Royal Regiment of Scotland</a>. The Army retains responsibility for these and for the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scots" title="Royal Scots">Royal Scots</a> Museum and <a href="/wiki/Royal_Scots_Dragoon_Guards" title="Royal Scots Dragoon Guards">Royal Scots Dragoon Guards</a> Museum.<sup id="cite_ref-osowska_148-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-osowska-148">[148]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Military_Tattoo">Military Tattoo</span></h3>
<p><a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Rellink&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Rellink (page does not exist)">Template:Rellink</a>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh_castle_tattoo.jpg" title="File:Edinburgh castle tattoo.jpg">File:Edinburgh castle tattoo.jpg</a>  <div class="thumbcaption"><a href="/wiki/Royal_Marines" title="Royal Marines">Royal Marines</a> emerging from Edinburgh Castle during the Military Tattoo 2005</div></div></div>
<p>A series of performances known as the Edinburgh Military Tattoo takes place on the Esplanade each year during August. The basis of each performance is a parade of the massed <a href="/wiki/Pipes_and_drums" title="Pipes and drums" class="mw-redirect">pipes and drums</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Scottish_regiments&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Scottish regiments (page does not exist)">Scottish regiments</a>, and since its inception in 1950 the Tattoo has developed a complex format which includes a variety of performers invited from around the world, although still with a largely military focus. The climax of the evening is the lone <a href="/wiki/Bagpipes" title="Bagpipes">piper</a> on the castle battlements, playing a <a href="/w/index.php?title=P%C3%ACobaireachd&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Pìobaireachd (page does not exist)">pibroch</a> in memory of dead comrades-in-arms, followed by massed bands joining in a medley of traditional Scottish tunes. The Tattoo attracts an annual audience of around 217,000 people, and is broadcast in some 30 countries to a television audience estimated at 100 million.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a href="/wiki/File:One_OClock_Gun.JPG" title="File:One OClock Gun.JPG">File:One OClock Gun.JPG</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">The One O'Clock Gun being fired from Mill's Mount Battery</div></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="One_O.27Clock_Gun">One O'Clock Gun</span></h3>
<p>The One O'Clock Gun is a <a href="/wiki/Time_signal" title="Time signal">time signal</a>, fired every day at precisely 13:00, excepting Sunday, Good Friday and Christmas Day. The 'Time Gun' was established in 1861 as a time signal for ships in the harbour of <a href="/wiki/Leith" title="Leith">Leith</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Firth_of_Forth" title="Firth of Forth">Firth of Forth</a>, <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a> away. It complemented the '<a href="/w/index.php?title=Time_Ball&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Time Ball (page does not exist)">Time Ball</a>', which was installed on the <a href="/wiki/Nelson_Monument,_Edinburgh" title="Nelson Monument, Edinburgh">Nelson Monument</a> in 1852, but was useless as a visual signal in foggy weather. Because sound travels relatively slowly (approximately <a href="/w/index.php?title=Template:Convert&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Template:Convert (page does not exist)">Template:Convert</a>), a map was produced in 1861 to show the actual time when the sound of the gun would be heard at various locations across Edinburgh.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup>
</p><p>The original gun was an 18-pound <a href="/wiki/Muzzleloader" title="Muzzleloader">muzzle-loading</a> cannon, which needed four men to load, and was fired from the Half Moon Battery. This was replaced in 1913 by a 32-pound <a href="/wiki/Breech-loading_weapon" title="Breech-loading weapon">breech-loader</a>, and in May 1952 by a <a href="/w/index.php?title=Ordnance_QF_25_pounder&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Ordnance QF 25 pounder (page does not exist)">25-pound Howitzer</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> The present One O'Clock Gun is an <a href="/w/index.php?title=L118_Light_Gun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="L118 Light Gun (page does not exist)">L118 Light Gun</a>, brought into service on 30 November 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-155" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-155">[155]</a></sup>
</p><p>The gun is now fired from Mill's Mount Battery, on the north face of the castle, by the District Gunner from the <a href="/w/index.php?title=105th_Regiment_Royal_Artillery_(Volunteers)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="105th Regiment Royal Artillery (Volunteers) (page does not exist)">105th Regiment Royal Artillery (Volunteers)</a>. Although the gun is no longer required for its original purpose, the ceremony has become a popular tourist attraction. The longest-serving District Gunner, Staff Sergeant <a href="/w/index.php?title=Thomas_McKay_(gunner)&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Thomas McKay (gunner) (page does not exist)">Thomas McKay</a> <a href="/wiki/Order_of_the_British_Empire" title="Order of the British Empire">MBE</a>, nicknamed "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Tam_the_Gun&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Tam the Gun (page does not exist)">Tam the Gun</a>", fired the One O'Clock Gun from 1979 until his retirement in January 2005. McKay helped establish the One O'Clock Gun Association, which opened a small exhibition at Mill's Mount, and published a book entitled <i>What Time Does Edinburgh's One O'clock Gun Fire?</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup> In 2006 Sergeant Jamie Shannon, nicknamed "Shannon the Cannon", became the 29th District Gunner,<sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> and in 2006 Bombardier Allison Jones became the first woman to fire the gun.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbol_of_Edinburgh">Symbol of Edinburgh</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a href="/wiki/File:Edinburgh-coa.png" title="File:Edinburgh-coa.png">File:Edinburgh-coa.png</a>  <div class="thumbcaption">Edinburgh Castle as it appears on the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Coat_of_arms_of_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Coat of arms of Edinburgh (page does not exist)">coat of arms</a> of the city</div></div></div>
<p>The castle has become a recognisable symbol of Edinburgh, and of Scotland.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> It appears, in stylised form, on the <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms" title="Coat of arms">coats of arms</a> of the <a href="/w/index.php?title=City_of_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="City of Edinburgh (page does not exist)">City of Edinburgh</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=University_of_Edinburgh&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="University of Edinburgh (page does not exist)">University of Edinburgh</a>. During the <a href="/wiki/World_War_II" title="World War II">Second World War</a> it featured on the badge of <a href="/w/index.php?title=No._603_Squadron_RAF&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="No. 603 Squadron RAF (page does not exist)">No. 603 (City of Edinburgh) Squadron</a> based at <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Airport#History" title="Edinburgh Airport">RAF Turnhouse</a> (now Edinburgh Airport).<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> Images of the castle are used as a logo by organisations including <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Rugby" title="Edinburgh Rugby">Edinburgh Rugby</a>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Evening_News" title="Edinburgh Evening News">Edinburgh Evening News</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Hibernian_F.C." title="Hibernian F.C.">Hibernian F.C.</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Edinburgh_Marathon&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Edinburgh Marathon (page does not exist)">Edinburgh Marathon</a>. It also appears on the "<a href="/w/index.php?title=Castle_series_stamps&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Castle series stamps (page does not exist)">Castle series</a>" of Royal Mail <a href="/wiki/Postage_stamp" title="Postage stamp">postage stamps</a>, and has been represented on various issues of <a href="/wiki/Banknotes_of_the_pound_sterling" title="Banknotes of the pound sterling">banknotes</a> issued by Scottish clearing banks. In the 1960s the castle was illustrated on £5 notes issued by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=National_Commercial_Bank_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="National Commercial Bank of Scotland (page does not exist)">National Commercial Bank of Scotland</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> and since 1987 it has featured on the reverse of £1 notes issued by the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Royal_Bank_of_Scotland&amp;action=edit&amp;redlink=1" class="new" title="Royal Bank of Scotland (page does not exist)">Royal Bank of Scotland</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-scotbanks_162-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-scotbanks-162">[162]</a></sup> Since 2009 the castle, as part of Edinburgh's World Heritage Site, has appeared on £10 notes issued by the <a href="/wiki/Clydesdale_Bank" title="Clydesdale Bank">Clydesdale Bank</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> The castle is a focal point for annual fireworks displays which mark Edinburgh's <a href="/wiki/Hogmanay" title="Hogmanay">Hogmanay</a> (new year) celebrations,<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> and the end of the <a href="/wiki/Edinburgh_Festival" title="Edinburgh Festival">Edinburgh Festival</a> in the summer.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup>
</p>
